description: From Middle English holi, hali, from Old English hāliġ, hāleġ (“holy, consecrated, sacred, venerated, godly, saintly, ecclesiastical, pacific, tame”), from Proto-West Germanic *hailag, from Proto-Germanic *hailagaz (“holy, bringing health”), from Proto-Germanic *hailaz (“healthy, whole”), from Proto-Indo-European *kóh₂ilus (“healthy, whole”), equivalent to whole +‎ -y.

entries.meaning: Dedicated to a religious purpose or a god.
examples: I'm planning to visit the holy city of Jerusalem this Christmas.

entries.meaning: Morally perfect or flawless, or nearly so.
examples: My grandmother is a very holy woman.

entries.meaning: Separated or set apart from (something unto something or someone else).
Set apart or dedicated for a specific purpose, or for use by a single entity or person.
(slang) Used as an intensifier in various interjections.
examples: Holy cow, I can’t believe he actually lost the race!
Those children next door are holy terrors!

entries.meaning: (archaic) A thing that is extremely holy; used almost exclusively in Holy of Holies.
examples: The holy of holies, a cubical space of ten cubits on the side, was separated from the larger antechamber by four columns, which were also covered with gold and stood upon silver sockets; they bore a second curtain of four colors.
